posts.author: Jack Bauer
posts.content:
Hey I was trying to do wizard again on the Arelith server. I was intending to take the extra gifts of +2 endurance and +2 intellect. I would like to try and get as many epic spell focuses as possible, while including the spells epic mummy dust and Epic Dragon Knight. I also wouldn't mind having a focus around the flesh to stone spell or possibly just using summoned creatures to take me to max level. I look forward to hearing what suggestions you folks have. Thanks!

-Jack Bauer

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
These are the Spellcraft skill prereqs (earliest level possible) for each epic spell:

mummy dust 15 (21)
dragon knight 22 (21)
greater ruin 25 (22)
epic mage armor 26 (23)
hellball 32 (29)
epic warding 34 (31): this feat impossible on Lvl 30 cap unless server changed Spcr prereq (only allotted ranks allowed in vanilla)

Each Epic Spell Focus requires spell focus and grtr spell focus in each applicable school.  FtoS is Transmutation.

Total epic feats, Level 30 cap = 4 general + 3 wiz bonus = 7

Maximum epic spell focus possible, Level 30 cap = 5 (10 feats pre epic, 5 feats epic)

It's up to you to choose what makes the most sense for your intentions.

Keep in mind that for each pair of Grt INT feats "traded" in for epic spell feats, your DC will drop by 1 universally (all schools).

Also, for PvP, you will almost certainly need spell pen, grtr spell pen, epic spell pen (2 pre-epic feats + 1 epic feat)

posts.author: Jack Bauer
posts.content: Thanks for the help, so is 1 natural intellect = 1 dc on a spell? It is possible I could make my race drow for an extra +2 intelligence. Or is it that the greater int feat on it's own adds +1 dc to spells cast of all schools?

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
It's not the ability level but the ability modifier that affects DC.  +1 ability affects nothing (except +1 STR does boost towing capacity).  +2 ability raises the modifier by 1.

It calculates like this: DC = 10 + spell level + ability modifier + feat modifier.

So, using a dual spell focus example (many ppl like to take evoc and necro so we'll use those for an example), it would take 4 pre-epic feats (SpF: Evoc/GSpF: Evoc and SpF: Necro/GSpF: Necro ) to qualify to take Epic SpF: Evoc and Epic SpF: Necro.  The epic foci would raise Evoc and Necro spells by DC 2. The other schools' DCs would gain nothing.   However, if you chose Grt INT x 2 instead, it would raise all schools by the modifier, 1.  In the first case, you'd gain +1 DC in the 2 focused schools over the corresponding investment in Grt INTx2 but the remaining schools would remain at status quo. 

So, it comes down to how dedicated you intend your spellcasting to be.  With little diversion away from the 2 focused schools, it's best to invest in their corresponding epic focus.  With a wide spectrum of spellcasting using spells that allow saves, it's best to focus on your primary ability using Grt Ability bumps, if given the choice, to boost all schools evenly.

DC does not rely on "natural" ability modifier so if you can reach the +12 ability cap by a combo of item props and (in this case) Empowered Fox Cunning pre-buff (up to +7 INT), you'll be able to raise the DCs of all schools by +6.  Empowered Fox should be an automatic pre-buff for all high-WIZ types.

A good tactic to optimize success of FtoS is to precede it with Bestow Curse, another Transmutation.  That spell saves vs. Will which is typically very low on warrior types.  When you follow-up with FtoS, you'll gain a 1 point advantage (modifier) by lowering the CON of the foe by 2 points.  Fort is the hardest save to beat with warrior types, especially CoTs.

I agree somewhat about the Drow subrace INT boost advantage.  The problem with with elven spellcasters is that they give up Fort with the racial bias, so in a theoretical Fort duel between elven wiz and human wiz (or dwarven wiz, for that matter), elves should lose most of the time due to their racial CON penalty.
